School of Chemical Engineering and Technology Tianjin University Tianjin 300350 PR China Metal-free catalyst with good biocompatibility and sustainability is a fascinating alternative for metal-based catalyst, especially in the production of fine chemicals sensitive to metal impurities. Catalytic hydrogenation with formic acid (FA) is regarded as a sustainable and green strategy for organic hydrogenation, in which the development of metal-free catalyst is an arduous but significant challenge. In this work, a dual-doping strategy of N and B was chosen to build the desired base and acid sites in carbon materials for simultaneous activation of hydrogen donor FA and acceptor quinoline. In the additive-free system, N, B dual-doped metal-free catalyst BNC-900 showed outstanding catalytic performance for the hydrogenation of quinoline with FA, 91.64% conversion of quinoline and 93.62% selectivity for 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline were achieved. Moreover, it exhibited satisfying stability and tolerance for diverse substrates. According to the experimental data and DFT calculation results, pyridinic N and BC2O were revealed to be the primary active sites for FA and quinoline respectively and act synergistically. Besides, it was found that the formation of B-N bond derived from the neutralization of the electron donor and acceptor may hinder the construction of highly active sites. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords N, B dual-doped carbon Metal-free catalyst Hydrogenation Formic acid Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Selective hydrogenation is one of the most crucial organic transformations for the synthesis of fine chemicals or pharmaceuticals [1]. The hydrogen stored in formic acid (FA) can be extracted and used for diverse selective catalytic transformation, which has been regarded as an efficient and selective hydrogenation strategy over the past decades [2]. In addition to its high hydrogen storage capacity and low toxicity, FA is a renewable and sustainable hydrogen donor, which could be produced from biomass or the reduction of CO2 [3]. Therefore, catalytic hydrogenation with FA not only has a positive environmental impact but also benefits the sustainable industrial development [4]. However, like most hydrogen donor molecules, the limited hydrogenation capacity of FA requires efficient catalysts, so the construction of efficient catalysts is a crucial challenge for hydrogenation with FA. At present, metal-based catalysts are indispensable for the efficient activation of FA [5–7]. Researchers have developed many strategies to improve the performance of metal-based catalysts, such as metal-support interaction [8–10], single atom strategy [11], alloys [12] and so on [13,14]. Although these metal-based catalysts have achieved promising results, the problem often arising is the inevitable metal leaching in the acidic medium [15]. Even worse, for many fine chemicals applied in biological and electronic fields, extremely trace metal impurities may cause a fatal blow to the product safety and performance. Besides, a trace amount of CO, the possible by-product of FA decomposition, could severely deactivate some metal-based catalysts [1]. Therefore, development of metal-free catalysts for organic hydrogenation with FA is necessary and significant. Carbon-based materials are typical nonmetallic materials with abundant natural reserves and adjustable atomic/morphological structure, which is identified as ideal metal-free catalysts [16–19]. In past decades, some achievements on the hydrogenation of nitroarene with hydrazine [20], hydrazine hydrate [21,22] or NaBH4 [23,24] over metal-free carbon catalysts were declared, in which the heteroatom sites or defects in carbon skeleton may play a positive role. However, these works mostly focused on relatively active hydrogen donor molecules, which are unfortunately toxic and explosive. Moreover, it is difficult to realize the activation of FA over these metal-free catalysts. Recently, Gao et al. constructed the carbon materials with pyrone-like structure as active sites via oxidation and pyrolysis of activated carbon and applied them in the reduction of Cr6+ with FA [25]. It was also achieved over C3N4-derived N-doped carbon by Liu's group [26]. However, when it comes to hydrogenation of organic compounds, such as 4-NP, it still required NaBH4. Chen's group has tried to reduce nitrobenzene over P-doped carbon nanotubes with diverse hydrogen donors and satisfying results were obtained with hydrazine hydrate and NaBH4. However, the case of FA fell short of ideal. Only N-formanilide instead of aniline was obtained with necessary additive Et3N [27]. Therefore, due to the difficulty and complexity of FA activation process, the selective hydrogenation of organic compounds with FA is still a tough issue. N-heterocycles are interesting molecules with important applications, mainly as bioactive compounds [28]. In particular, 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline and its related structures constitute a ubiquitous scaffold in natural products and widely used in drugs, agrochemicals and other fields sensitive to metal impurities [29]. Furthermore, in the particular case of N-heteroarenes, the possible poisoning by either starting materials or products also restricts the application of metal-based catalysts [30]. Therefore, it is a hard challenge with great significance to construct metal-free catalysts to realize efficient hydrogenation of typical N-heterocycle quinoline with FA. Heteroatom-doping is an attractive method to modulate the charge distribution and physicochemical properties of pristine carbon. In particular, dual-doping strategy is a possible route to form multiple active sites and develop efficient carbon-based metal-free catalysts. N are typical electron donors [31], while B often act as electron-deficient dopants in carbon materials [32]. In this work, to realize the simultaneous activation of quinoline and FA, dual-doping strategy of N and B was chosen to endow carbon material with base and acid sites. Furthermore, efficient hydrogenation of quinoline with FA was achieved over N, B dual-doped carbon as expected. The effect of N, B co-doping on catalytic performance and possible active sites were discussed by experimental and theoretical study. It is academically interesting and practically instructive for designing advanced catalysts. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation Inexpensive biomass chitin was selected as nitrogen and carbon source. Boric acid was chosen as boron dopant. Initially, 0.5 g boric acid was dissolved in 10 mL deionized water. Then boric acid solution was transferred into the suspension of 2.5 g chitin in 50 mL ethanol and the mixture was stirred for 4 h. Subsequently, the solvent was slowly removed under vacuum. The obtained solid was dried in vacuum at 60 ℃. The obtained powder was pyrolyzed at 900 ℃ for 2 h under Ar atmosphere to yield N, B dual-doped carbon, denoted as BNC-900. The single-doped carbons were prepared similarly. BC-900 was obtained with cellulose instead of chitin, while NC-900 was prepared from pure chitin. BNC-T samples were obtained at different temperature (T = 700, 800, 900, 1000 ℃). The preparation details of all catalyst are summarized in Table S1. 2.2 Characterization The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of carbon materials were collected on Smartlab (Rigaku, Japan) in the range of 10–80 º (4 º/min). Raman spectra were recorded on LabRAM HR Evolution (Horiba, Japan) with a 532 nm laser. SEM images were obtained by Regulus 8100 (Hitachi, Japan). TEM images and high angle annular dark field (HAADF) micrographs were collected by JEM-F200 (JEOL, Japan). EDS mapping analyses were obtained by Ultim Max (Oxford, English). Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) analysis was employed by Agilent 5110 (Agilent, U.S.A). Elemental analysis (EA) results were detected by DELTA V Advantage (Thermo Scientific, Germany). Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) surface areas and pore volumes of the nanocomposites were measured on ASAP 2460 (Micromeritics, U.S.A). The pore size distributions were obtained by Barret-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were recorded on Thermo Scientific K-Alpha+ (Thermo Scientific, U.S.A.). 1H NMR and MS spectra were recorded on Bruker AVANCE III HD (400 MHz) and Bruker Micro TOF-Q II, respectively. GC–MS was analyzed on GC-Agilent 6980A and MS-Agilent 5973C. 2.3 Evaluation of catalysts All catalytic reactions were carried out in a 30 mL stainless reaction vessel with a polytetrafluoroethylene lining under magnetic stirring. Typically, there were 0.25 mmol substrate, 3 mL solvent and 30 mg catalyst putted into the autoclave. After filled with 2 MPa N2, the reaction vessel was kept at 200 ℃ under magnetic stirring. As reaction completed, gas chromatography (GC) (GC-4000A, EWAI, China) or high performance liquid chromatograph (HPLC, Agilent1100, U.S.A.) were used to analyze the reaction mixture. And the products were further confirmed by 1H NMR and MS. GC-mass was also employed to monitor the hydrogenation of quinoline with formic acid. Quinoline conversion and 1,2,3.4-tetrahydroquinoline selectivity are defined according to Eqs. (1) and (2), respectively. TOF equals to the moles of the converted substrate over one gram catalyst in an hour. (1) Conversion ( % ) = [ 1 − ( [ q u i n o l i n e ] o u t [ q u i n o l i n e ] i n ) ] × 100 (2) Selectivity ( % ) = [ 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 − t e t r a h y d r o q u i n o l i n e ] o u t 1 − [ q u i n o l i n e ] o u t × 100 [quinoline]in is the concentration of quinoline in the original solution, [quinoline]out and [1,2,3.4-tetrahydroquinoline]out are the concentration of quinoline and 1,2,3.4-tetrahydroquinoline in the reaction mixture, respectively. 2.4 DFT calculations All the DFT calculations were conducted based on the Dmol3 code [33]. The electron-ion interactions were described by the Projected Augmented-Wave (PAW) potentials, while the exchange-correlation interactions were calculated by employing the Perdew-Burke-Enzerhof (PBE) pseudopotentials of Generalized Gradient Approximation (GGA) [34,35]. The atomic basis functions were expanded in the double numerical plus polarization (DNP) basis set and the all the electrons method was adopted for core treatment. The global orbital cutoff was set as 4.1 Å and thermal smearing of 0.005 Ha for quick convergence. The self-consistent field (SCF) and geometrical optimization energy convergence threshold values were both set to be 10−5 and 10−6 Ha, and the max force and max displacement were set as 0.002 Ha/Å and 0.005 Å. The adsorption energy can be calculated according to the following formula: E ads = E ( A + B ) − E ( A ) − E ( B ) where Eads represents the adsorption energy, E( A + B ) is the calculated energy of adsorption configuration, E(A) and E(B) mean the calculated energy of substrate and adsorbent respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Materials characterization N, B dual-doped carbon was synthesized by a simple two-step methodology as shown in Scheme 1 . The morphologies of the prepared materials were characterized by SEM and TEM. The BNC-900 showed a stacking layered morphology with partial fibrosis in Fig. S1. In addition, a porous structure was observed in BNC-900 compared with NC-900, which may be attributed to the pore-creating effect of boric acid and its pyrolysis products [36,37]. As shown in Fig. 1a, BNC-900 was observed as stacking nanosheets with slight folds. Many short-range ordered lattice fringes with curved degree were shown in HRTEM image (Fig. 1b), indicating the existence of small graphene layers and turbostratic structure in BNC-900. Moreover, the elemental mapping images of BNC-900 indicated that N and B atoms were evenly distributed in the mesoporous carbon layers (Fig. 1c) revealing the successful dual-doping. To investigate the crystal structures, the XRD patterns of carbon materials were shown in Fig. 2a. All samples showed characteristic peaks at ∼25 o and 43 o, assigned to the (002) and (100) planes of graphite respectively. However, the broad peaks with low intensity indicated the co-existence of crystal and amorphous disorder structures, which was consistent with TEM. Furthermore, due to the promoting graphitization in pyrolysis, the peaks of BNC-T shifted to higher angles as the pyrolysis temperature increases [38].Compared with C-900 in Fig. S2a, there was a slight red shift of the (002) peak in single-doped carbons (BC-900 and NC-900) and dual-doped carbon (BNC-900), which may be assigned to the effect of heteroatoms leading to a smaller graphite layer distance [39]. The Raman spectra of samples in Fig. 2b displayed two obvious characteristic peaks at about 1353 and 1586 cm−1 corresponded to typical D band and G band, respectively. There was slight difference in ID /IG of BNC-T samples. However, visible difference in ID /IG was observed compared to that of C-900 in Fig. S2b. With the introduction of heteroatoms, the values of ID /IG significantly increased, implying that the incorporation of nitrogen and boron may destroy bond-stretching motion of C sp2 atoms and promote the generation of fragmentary graphite structures in samples [40]. To further investigate the surface elemental composition and the configurations, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) characterization was employed. The survey spectra (Fig. 3 ) revealed that the prepared BNC-T samples were composed of O, C, N and B, consistent with the EDS results (Fig. 1c). Increased intensities of N and B peaks were observed with the rising pyrolysis temperature of BNC-T samples. The elevated N and B content may be because the direct bonding route of B and N was promoted under high temperature [38]. The similar trend was also discovered in elemental analysis results summarized in Table 1 . Besides, compared with the high content of B and N in dual-doped BNC-900, the B content in BC-900 and N content in NC-900 were slender. In high-resolution C 1 s spectra of BNC-T samples displayed in Fig. 4a, the peak at 284.7 eV corresponded to the delocalized aromatic sp2 bond of the graphitic structure. The signal with a binding energy as 285.6 eV can be attributed to and CN bonds, confirming the successful doping of nitrogen. And the peak at 283.8 eV assigned to B-C bonds was observed in BNC-T samples except BNC-700, indicating it is hard to introduce B into carbon skeleton at low pyrolysis temperature [32,41]. The weak signals corresponding to C=O and O−C=O bonds confirmed significant pyrolysis of oxygen-containing functional groups of precursors in carbonization process. According to the summarized configuration of C 1 s (Table S2), BCN-900 possessed the most abundant of CN and C-B bonds in the BNC-T samples, indicating its N and B amounts in carbon skeleton are the largest. For the N 1 s spectra (Fig. 4b), peaks at 398.7, 400.1, 401.8 and 403.6 eV can be clearly observed, which were corresponded to pyridinic N, pyrrolic N, graphitic N and N-oxides, respectively. As the pyrolysis temperature increasing, the signal of graphitic N became gradually stronger and the signal of N-oxides becomes fainter in BNC-T. Pyridinic N is an important Lewis basic site in catalysis according to previous work [42,43]. And the biggest content of pyridinic N was discovered in BNC-900 (Table S3). Moreover, an obvious peak corresponded to B-N bonds at 397.5 eV was observed in BNC-1000 [44]. It revealed the direct bonding of B and N is feasible under higher pyrolysis temperature and further verified the speculation for the trend of N and B contents in BNC-T samples [45]. However, the direct bonded B-N species may lead to the neutralization of electron-rich and electron-deficient dopants, preventing the formation of diverse active sites [44,46]. Besides, the peaks at 190.1, 191.1 and 192.1 eV in B 1 s spectra (Fig. 4c) can be attributed to B-N, BC2O and BCO2 bonds, respectively [47]. Considering the existence of oxygen-containing groups in precursor, there was no signal of B-C (∼189 eV) detected in BNC-T samples [48]. With the increasing pyrolysis temperature, the peaks area of B-N bonds in BCN-T showed significant increase tendency, which was consistent with the trend in N 1 s spectra. The amount of BCO2 phase decreased with rising pyrolysis temperature, due to the aggravating lessening of oxygen-containing groups in carbonation process. In addition, BNC-900 showed the maximum of BC2O species (Table S3), which could easily modulate electron distribution and provide effective acidic sites according to previous works [41,49]. The nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms of BNC-T samples were measured to study their textual properties. As summarized in Table 1, the surface areas of BNC-T samples were increasing with the rising pyrolysis temperature, which may be ascribed to released gas and breakdown products from precursors in pyrolysis process. Compared with single-doping carbons, BNC-900 displayed significantly larger surface area and smaller average pore size, which was consistent with SEM images. The pyrolysis of the precursor doped with N and B would possibly yield more released gas, thus leading to the increase of BET surface area upon doping of elements [37]. It also endowed BNC-900 with more active surface area and faster mass transfer in catalytic reactions. 3.2 Catalytic performance The catalytic performances of obtained metal-free catalysts were investigated in the hydrogenation of N-heterocycle with FA and quinoline was chosen as a benchmark substrate (Table 2 ). There were two products detected as 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline and N-formyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline. It was obvious that the reaction process leads to poor conversion and selectivity without catalyst or FA (Table 2, entry 1–2). Compared to C-900 (Table 2, entry 3) and single-doped carbons with minor improvement (Table 2, entry 4–5), the catalytic performances of all the four dual-doped carbon catalysts BNC-T were superior in conversion of quinoline and selectivity for 1,2,3.4-tetrahydroquinoline. It indicated that the heteroatom doping, especially dual-doping strategy, could improve the catalytic performance. While, the performance of BNC-700 was still unsatisfactory as 44.67% conversion (Table 2, entry 6). Its lack in C-B bonds indicates only small amounts of B species were introduced into carbon skeleton (Fig. 4a), which may be not conductive to tweak the electronic structure of carbon materials and improve the catalytical performance. For BNC-1000 (Table 2, entry 9), the performance with 59.02% conversion may be ascribed to excess direct B-N bonds hindering the formation of effective active sites (Fig. 4c). Besides, all B-dopped catalysts showed good selectivity. Among all the catalysts, BNC-900 (Table 2, entry 8) displayed the best catalytic performance with 73.77% conversion and 86.60% selectivity. Its TOF value was the highest as 6.15 × 10−4 mol·g−1·h−1 under same conditions. After further condition optimization, the conversion was up to 91.64% with the selectivity of 93.62% over BNC-900 (Table 2, entry 10). It may be ascribed to the largest amount of possible active sites pyridinic N and BC2O, which was also proved by the results of control experiments with additives (Table S4). When the reaction proceeded in the presence of phosphoric acid, which could protonate the basic sites of BNC-900, the conversion decreased to 47.33% (Table S4, entry 1). And for the case with triethylamine as additive to exclude acid sites, the conversion dropped significantly to 25.66% (Table S4, entry 2). It was proved that the base and acid sites in carbon catalysts play important roles in catalysis process. To further investigate the active sites, the content of pyridinic N and BC2O in different carbon catalysts were calculated and then summarized in Table S5. It was found that the content of pyridinic N and BC2O of carbon catalysts is approximately linear with their conversion, respectively (Fig. S4). However, it was difficult to obtain an appropriate fitting result when it comes to simple elemental content (Fig. S5), proving that although the doping of N and B influenced the activity of catalyst, the amount of pyridinic N and BC2O were the key factors. These results strongly suggested that the efficient performance of BNC-900 catalyst was due to the synergy of active sites BC2O and pyridinic N. In addition, FA can release H2 to participate in the hydrogenation of quinoline. To confirm the hydrogenation mechanism with FA over BNC-900, we conducted a control experiment under 2 MPa H2, instead of 3 eq FA, nearly no hydrogenation product was detected (Table S4, entry 3). It implied no H2 generation in the selective activation process of FA over BNC-900. In addition, the effect of solvent on the reaction was investigated over BNC-900 (Table S6). Although ethanol and n-hexane also showed tolerable conversion compared with water, their poor selectivity makes them impossible to be employed. Considering the environmental friendliness and low cost, water was finally chosen as solvent. The effect of catalyst amount, reaction temperature and hydrogen donor FA amount on catalytic performance were taken into account with BNC-900. As shown in Fig. S6a, the conversion of quinoline was up to 91.64% with a selectivity of 93.62%, when the amount of catalyst was up to 45 mg. While, it become lower as 47.04% conversion and 85.44% selectivity when the catalyst amount was 15 mg. In Fig. S6b, with the increase of temperature, the conversion of quinoline was elevated from 56.31% to 87.72%. Only slight fluctuations in selectivity of 1,2,3.4-tetrahydroquinoline were observed. Similar as the amount of catalyst, the reaction temperature affected obviously on the conversion of quinoline but slightly on the selectivity for 1,2,3.4-tetrahydroquinoline. However, it is different situation taking the amount of FA into account. When the amount of FA decreased to 0.5 mmol, the conversion is only 60.23% despite its ideal selectivity of 91.45% as shown in Fig. S6c. With the amount of FA increased to 1.0 mmol, the conversion increased up to 81.13% but the selectivity decreased to 70.72%. It revealed that although increasing the amount of FA can improve the conversion, excessive FA will promote the production of N-formyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline and reduce the selective for 1,2,3.4-tetrahydroquinoline To study the generality of the protocol, hydrogenation of several substituted quinolines over BNC-900 were examined (Table 3 ). Most of methylquinolines substituted at different positions were well tolerated with conversion more than 90% (Table 3, entry 2–5). The only exception was 8-methylquinoline with 81.08% conversion and 99.17% selectivity (Table 3, entry 6), which may be ascribed to the steric effect, leading to the inhibition to both activation of 8-methylquinoline and N-formylation of 8-methyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline. In the case of 6-substitued quinoline, both electron-releasing and electron-withdrawing groups were well tolerated with 78.61%−95.50% conversion (Table 3, entry 7–9). This metal-free catalytic hydrogenation system was also applicable to quinoxaline, the desired products 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoxaline were obtained in 94.07% conversion and 81.51% selectivity. It implied that the developed metal-free catalytic system could also be extended to the hydrogenation of other important N-heterocycles with FA. The stability and recyclability of catalysts are crucial issues in heterogeneous catalysis and industrial production. To demonstrate the durability of BNC-900, it was reused five times in catalytic hydrogenation of quinoline with FA. The conversion of quinoline and selectivity of 1,2,3.4-tetrahydroquinoline remained almost unchanged in all runs (Fig. 5 ). Furthermore, there was no obvious change in elemental composition according to elemental analysis of fresh and used catalyst (Fig. S7), which confirming the excellent stability of BNC-900. Hence, the high recyclability of the metal-free catalyst provides a promising candidate for catalytic hydrogenation of quinoline. 3.3 Theoretical calculations and speculated mechanism To further investigate the active sites in BNC-900, the adsorption of hydrogen donor FA and substrate quinoline was investigate by first-principles calculations (Fig. 6 and Table S7). The pyridinic N site possesses the lowest energy (−0.0693 eV) than that of other sites, indicating the pyridinic N is the most active center for adsorption and activation of FA. Considering the electronic effect of pyridinic N, the Lewis basicity may play crucial roles in FA adsorption. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations demonstrated that quinoline adsorption system with the lowest energy (−0.473 eV) is BC2O phase model, suggesting that BC2O may have a stronger capture capability of quinoline than other units in BNC-900. Besides, there is almost no spontaneous adsorption for FA and quinoline on the pyrrolic N according to its adsorption energies. The BCO2 and graphitic N showed only weak adsorption capacity of both FA and quinoline. As for bonded B-N case, only faint adsorption of quinoline was spontaneous (−0.232 eV), confirming the neutralization between electron donor (N) and acceptor (B) reduced the number of highly active sites. As expected, the pyridinic N and BC2O could act as efficient active sites for FA and quinoline during the transfer hydrogenation, which agrees well with the experimental data and characterization results. In the catalysis process (Scheme 2 ), the adsorption and deprotonation of FA are carried out at pyridinic N sites firstly. Simultaneously, the BC2O sites promotes the adsorption of quinoline. Subsequently, the generated HCOO− migrates to BC2O sites where quinoline was adsorbed. The release of CO2 generates the active hydrogen, which reacts with quinoline and produce 1,2,3.4-tetra-hydroquinoline. The different effective sites developed by the co-doping of N and B are speculated as the reason for efficient and selective hydrogenation of quinoline with FA. Moreover, the neutralization of N and B dopants could be avoided by proper pyrolysis conditions to yield the carbon materials with evenly distributed and isolated B and N active sites to realize their concerted catalysis. 4 Conclusion In summary, B and N dual-doped carbon material was prepared through pyrolysis method using cheap and N-containing biomass chitin as carbon source and nitrogen dopant, boric acid as boron dopant. As verified by TEM, XRD and Raman spectra, the fragmented graphene structure was discovered in amorphous carbon. X-ray photoelectron spectra and mapping images showed that B and N were uniformly doped in carbon skeleton. And the phases of B were discovered as BCO2, BC2O and B-N. The N displayed as pyridinic N, Pyrrolic N, graphitic N and oxidized N. In the additive-free system, this N, B co-doped carbon catalyst showed outstanding activity for the transfer hydrogenation of quinoline with FA, in which BNC-900 exhibited an excellent catalytic performance with 91.64% conversion and 93.62% selectivity for 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline. It exhibited satisfied stability in 5 runs cycling test and good tolerance for diverse substrates. According to experimental data and DFT calculation results, pyridinic N and BC2O sites may be active sites for FA and quinoline respectively and act synergistically. Furthermore, the B-N bond may neutralization the electron donor and acceptor, and further weaken the formation of highly active sites. This study achieved the efficient hydrogenation of quinoline with FA over metal-free catalysts and provided valuable guidance for rational design of metal-free catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Metal-free catalyst with good biocompatibility and sustainability is a fascinating alternative for metal-based catalyst, especially in the production of fine chemicals sensitive to metal impurities. Catalytic hydrogenation with formic acid (FA) is regarded as a sustainable and green strategy for organic hydrogenation, in which the development of metal-free catalyst is an arduous but significant challenge. In this work, a dual-doping strategy of N and B was chosen to build the desired base and acid sites in carbon materials for simultaneous activation of hydrogen donor FA and acceptor quinoline. In the additive-free system, N, B dual-doped metal-free catalyst BNC-900 showed outstanding catalytic performance for the hydrogenation of quinoline with FA, 91.64% conversion of quinoline and 93.62% selectivity for 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline were achieved. Moreover, it exhibited satisfying stability and tolerance for diverse substrates. According to the experimental data and DFT calculation results, pyridinic N and BC2O were revealed to be the primary active sites for FA and quinoline respectively and act synergistically. Besides, it was found that the formation of B-N bond derived from the neutralization of the electron donor and acceptor may hinder the construction of highly active sites.
coredata.dc:title: N, B dual-doped carbons as metal-free catalysts for hydrogenation of quinoline with formic acid
